chapter: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a function of the middle ear?
questions.explanation:
Transduction of sound (mechanical energy to electrical impulses) is done by the sensory system 
of the cochlea. It is not a function of the middle ear. The functions of the middle ear are: • Conduction of sound through impedance matching or transformer action 257 
Sold by @itachibot • Protection of inner ear • Amplification of sound intensity
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 2: What is the lever ratio of the ear ossicles?
questions.explanation:
The lever ratio of the ear ossicles is 1.3:1. The handle of the malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of the incus, providing a 
mechanical advantage of 1.3.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 3: The effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane is much larger than the area of stapes 
footplate. Which of the following is the most accurate value of the average ratio between the 
two?
questions.explanation:
258 
Sold by @itachibot The ratio of effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane to the area of footplate of stapes 
(areal ratio) is 17:1 . Effective vibratory area of TM = 55 mm2 Footplate area = 3.2 mm2 Areal ratio = Effective vibratory area of tympanic membrane ÷ stapes footplate area
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 4: What is the transformer ratio of the middle ear?
questions.explanation:
The transformer ratio of the middle ear is 22:1 The middle ear has to conduct sound waves from a low impedance tympanic membrane to a high 
impedance oval window. This is done by matching their impedances. It is called transforming 
action. Transformer ratio =Areal ratio × Lever ratio 259 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 5: What is the natural resonance of the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation:
The natural resonance of the tympanic membrane is 800 – 1600 Hz. Aging causes a decrease in the external ear resonance amplitude due to the collapse of the 
external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane becoming senile. This factor has to be 
considered to appropriately diagnose hearing loss and in the selection of hearing aids. Natural resonance and efficiency of auditory apparatus: • External auditory canal- 3000 Hz • Tympanic membrane- 800–1600 Hz • Middle ear- 800 Hz • Ossicular chain- 500–2000 Hz
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following factors do not contribute to the impedance matching mechanism of 
the middle ear?

options.a: Lever action of ossicles providing mechanical advantage of 1.3
options.b: Phase difference between the oval and round windows
options.c: Relatively large area of the tympanic membrane compared to stapes footplate
options.d: More movements at the centre of the tympanic membrane than at periphery

questions.explanation:
Movements of the tympanic membrane are more at the periphery than at the center, where the 
malleus handle is attached. This is called the curved membrane effect and it contributes to the 
impedance matching mechanism of the ear. Other factors responsible for the impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear are: • The lever action of the ossicles- handle of malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of 
incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3. • Hydraulic action of the tympanic membrane- relatively large area of the tympanic membrane 
compared to the stapes footplate. 260 
Sold by @itachibot • The medial side of the tympanic membrane is multiphasic whereas the lateral side is uniphasic. 
This provides a multiple integrated multilever mechanical advantage.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 7: Who proposed the travelling wave theory of cochlear mechanics?
questions.explanation:
The traveling wave theory was proposed by von Békésy. It states that a sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a 
particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment. Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower 
ones towards the apex.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 8: What is the endocochlear potential recorded from the scala media?
questions.explanation:
Endocochlear potential is a direct current (DC) potential recorded from scala media. It is +80 mV 
and is generated from the stria vascularis by Na+/K+-ATPase pump and provides a source of 
energy for cochlear transduction. It is present at rest and does not require a sound stimulus.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 9: You are an intern performing the tuning fork tests on a patient who presented to the ENT 
OPD with complaints of decreased hearing in the left ear. Which of the following tuning forks 
is most commonly used for the routine clinical assessment for such patients?
questions.explanation:
A tuning fork of 512 Hz is most commonly used for routine clinical assessment in ENT. Tuning forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher 
frequencies have a shorter decay time and are thus not routinely preferred.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 10: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with hearing loss in the right ear. A 512 Hz 
tuning fork is used, which highlights the Rinne test is positive bilaterally. What is the likely 
inference?

options.a: Air conduction is better than bone conduction
options.b: Bone conduction is better than air conduction
options.c: Air conduction is equal to bone conduction
options.d: Bone conduction is worse than that of examiner's

questions.explanation: Rinne test is positive when the air conduction (AC) is longer or louder than bone conduction (BC).
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 11: What should be the minimum hearing loss in a patient for the Rinne test to be negative?
questions.explanation: The minimum hearing loss for the Rinne test to be negative is 15-20dB. Negative Rinne (BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 12: 253 
Sold by @itachibot In a patient presenting with a conductive type of hearing loss, a negative Rinne test with a 512 
Hz tuning fork indicates a minimum air-bone gap of?
questions.explanation:
The negative Rinne test for 512 Hz indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 30 dB. 261 
Sold by @itachibot Rinne’s test is a tuning fork test performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 
128, 256, 512, and 1024 Hz. Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops 
hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air 
conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC) i.e. AC>BC. The inferences are as follows: • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal 
people and people with sensorineural deafness. • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. As a general prediction, a negative Rinne's test with any tuning fork frequency suggests a 
minimum hearing loss of at least 15 - 20 dB.The table below indicates a rough minimum air-bone 
gap for negative Rinne's test at different frequencies: A prediction of the air-bone gap can be made based on the combination of tuning fork tests of 
256, 512, and 1024 Hz: • A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 20-30 dB. • A Rinne test negative for 256 and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap 
of 30-45 dB. • A Rinne test negative for 256, 512, and 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 45-60 dB. Minimum air-bone

questions.question:
Question 13: You are a first-year resident performing the tuning fork tests on the following patients to 
assess their hearing loss. Which one of them will you expect to have a positive Rinne test?

options.a: A child with chronic suppurative otitis media
options.b: An adolescent man with impacted wax

questions.explanation:
A positive Rinne test is seen in presbycusis, which is a type of sensorineural deafness. A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is longer than bone conduction, as seen in 
normal ear and sensorineural deafness. A negative Rinne test indicates that bone conduction is longer than air conduction, as seen in 
conditions causing in conductive deafness such as chronic suppurative otitis media, impacted 
wax, and otosclerosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 14: A middle-aged man diagnosed with Ménière's disease presented with severe unilateral 
hearing loss. Which of the following would be the most likely finding on performing the 
Rinne test on this patient?
questions.explanation:
Patients diagnosed with Ménière's disease present with a sensorineural type of hearing loss. 
A false negative Rinne test is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. 262 
Sold by @itachibot The patient doesn’t respond to air conduction but is able to hear when a tuning fork is placed over 
the mastoid process i.e. bone conduction > air conduction. Hence reported as negative. This is 
a false negative because this response to bone conduction is from the opposite ear due to 
transcranial transmission of sound.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 15: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing 
loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne 
test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with 
complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was 
negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss as a consequence of 
untreated suppurative labyrinthitis and Rinne's test is a false negative in this case. Initially, the patient had a positive fistula test, which implies that the labyrinth is still functioning. 
Rinne's test is positive which could be due to normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss. Currently, the patient has a negative fistula test which implies that the labyrinth is dead. This is 
an example of severe sensorineural hearing loss and here, Rinne test is a false negative. If intermittent pressure applied to the external ear produces vertigo and nystagmus, it is a positive 
fistula test. The pressure changes in the external ear are transmitted to the labyrinth. This is 
suggestive of abnormal communication between the middle ear and the inner ear.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is false about the test being performed on a patient by an ENT 
resident as shown below?

options.a: It is lateralized to worse ear in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome
options.b: It is heard equally on both sides in normal individual
options.c: It is lateralized towards better ear in cochlear otosclerosis
options.d: It is lateralized towards worse ear in Ménière’s disease

questions.explanation:
The image shows the Weber test being performed. Ménière’s disease causes sensorineural hearing 
loss and hence Weber test is lateralized towards the better ear. In Weber's test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and 
the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural 
deafness. Option A: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, 
Weber is lateralized to the worse ear. Option B: In normal individuals, the sound is heard equally in both ears. So Weber is not 
lateralized. Option C: Cochlear otosclerosis causes sensorineural deafness, whereas stapedial otosclerosis 
causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the better ear in case of cochlear 
otosclerosis. 263 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 17: A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the examiner alternately closes and 
opens the ear canal of the patient by pressing the tragus inwards to examine the effect of 
occlusion on hearing. What is the test being performed here?
questions.explanation:
Bing test is being performed in the given clinical scenario. It is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on hearing. A 
vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid. The examiner alternately closes and opens the ear 
canal by pressing the tragus inwards. Bing positive: A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear 
canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open. Bing negative: A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 18: A young female diagnosed with otosclerosis presented to the ENT OPD with worsening 
hearing loss. Which of the following will be the most likely observation on the Bing test?

options.a: Hears louder when canal is occluded
options.c: Hears softer when canal is occluded
options.d: The test is said to be positive

questions.explanation:
The patient diagnosed with otosclerosis will have a conductive type of hearing loss and will 
appreciate no change in the Bing test. Here, the Bing test is said to be negative. Bing test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on 
hearing. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid. The examiner alternately closes and 
opens the ear canal by pressing on the tragus inwards. Bing positive: A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear 
canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open. Bing negative: A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question: Question 19: In which of the following diseases would you find a negative Gelle's test?
questions.explanation:
264 
Sold by @itachibot Gelle’s test is negative in otosclerosis. It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes 
footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound (positive Gelle's test). But, in an ear 
with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear 
the sound (negative Gelle's test). It was once a popular test to find out stapes fixation in otosclerosis but has now been superseded 
by tympanometry.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 20: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The 
Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the 
interpretation?
questions.explanation:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness. Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates right-sided conductive deafness or left-sided 
sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne's test is positive on both the ears, conductive deafness can be 
ruled out and hence, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.
questions.chapter_heading: Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests

questions.question:
Question 21: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following 
structures will be affected?
questions.explanation:
Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) damages the outer hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the 
cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells. NIHL occurs after chronic exposure to less intense sounds. The damage caused by noise trauma 
depends on the frequency of noise (frequency of 2000 to 3000 Hz causes more damage) intensity, 
duration of the noise, and preexisting ear disease. The audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss shows a typical notch at 4000Hz both for air and 
bone conduction known as acoustic dip/boiler's notch. Patients at this stage complain of 
high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty hearing in noisy surroundings. Pre-employment and annual 
audiograms for persons working at places where noise is above 85 dB (A) help in the early 265 
Sold by @itachibot detection of NIHL. The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz. Below 20 Hz, the vibrations are 
infra-audible, and above 20,000 Hz, they are ultra-sonic. Pure tone audiometry can detect only up 
to 8000 Hz. Extended high-frequency audiometry is recommended for early detection of hearing loss, as it can 
identify hearing impairments before the frequencies necessary for speech comprehension are 
affected. Distortion product otoacoustic emissions is a more sensitive tool than conventional 
audiometry, particularly in children under 5 years old for early detection of hearing loss. A noise of ˜0 dB(A) SPL (acceptable noise levels, sound pressure level), 8 hours a day for 5 days 
per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour. As per WHO, 85 
dB(A) is considered the highest safe exposure level up to a maximum of 8 hours. The silence zone extends to a distance of 100 meters around the premises of hospitals, nursing 
homes, educational institutions, and courts. Permissible limits of noise as per the noise pollution (Regulation and Control) rules: Noise levels are measured in dB(A), which prioritizes middle-range frequencies for assessing 
noise-induced hearing loss while giving less weightage to low and high frequencies. The image below shows an acoustic dip at 4000Hz: Day(6 am to 10 pm) limits in
